issue.title: std::polar should require a non-negative rho

discussion.p: Different implementations give different answers for the following code:

Which is correct? Or neither?
In this list, Howard Hinnant wrote:

blockquote.p:
I've read this over several times. I've consulted C++11, C11, and IEC 10967-3. [snip]
I'm finding:

li.p: The magnitude of a complex number == abs(c) == hypot(c.real(), c.imag()) and is always non-negative (by all three of the above standards).
Therefore no complex number exists for which abs(c) < 0.
Therefore when the first argument to std::polar (which is called rho) is negative, no complex number can be formed which meets the post-conidtion that abs(c) == rho.

blockquote.p: One could argue that this is already covered in /3, but I think it's worth making explicit.

resolution.p: This wording is relative to N4140.

blockquote.pre: template<class T> complex<T> polar(const T& rho, const T& theta = 0);

blockquote.p:
-?- Requires: rho shall be non-negative, non-NaN, and non-infinity. theta shall be finite.
-9- Returns: The complex value corresponding to a complex number whose magnitude is rho and whose phase angle is theta.
